text.text: (Porto-Gonçalves, Carlos Walter, , pp. 39-43).

The time intervals referenced here for Europe are based on definitions from the Britannica Encyclopedia. However, there is no single, universally applicable periodization for the entire region (Barzun, J. et al., , Europe History ; Violatti, C., , Idade da Pedra).

Prerequisites

To better understand the concept of time, we suggest that readers first study the following resources:

  • Natural Limits: Introduces the reader to the concept of limits using examples from the human body and liquids.
  • Understanding the time: a study of how different civilizations measure time.
  • Understanding the time continuity: an examination of time in nature.

Introduction

Nature has been forming groups since the dawn of time, starting with the Big Bang (History Tracers, , Introduction to groups), and as natural beings, we instinctively follow this pattern. One notable example is the "Three-Age System" developed by Christian Jurgensen Thomsen, which classifies human prehistory into the Stone Age, Bronze Age, and Iron Age (Heizer, R. F., , pp. 259 ; Barzun, J. et al., , History of Europe ; Violatti, C., , Stone Ages). While Thomsen’s conclusions are significant in a European context, the question arises: can this model also be applied to the Americas (Abya Yala)?

The Three-Age System in America (Abya Ayala)

In examining Robert F. Heizer's work, the following key points stand out:
  • He categorizes human prehistory into distinct periods: the Stone Age, the Bronze Age ( - A.C), and the Iron Age ( - ) (Heizer, R. F., ).
  • Heizer's work contains assertions suggesting European cultural superiority over Indigenous cultures (Heizer, R. F., , pp. 260 - 261), which lacks empirical basis (History Tracers, , Who claimed that indigenous peoples are inherently different?).
  • He also refutes the belief in a 6,000-year-old Earth, highlighting its inaccuracy (Heizer, R. F., , pp. 261 - 262).

The misconception of Indigenous peoples in America (Abya Yala) as "savages" reflects a profound misunderstanding of their history. For example, the civilization of Caral in Peru (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ; de la Morena, Raquel, , Los misterios de la ciudad más antigua de América ; Moras, Roberto., ), potentially developed a form of writing (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008 ; History Tracers, , The writing system) and built complex structures, positioning their city as one of the earliest urban centers in the world (Mann, Charles C., , pp. 1008).
Figure 1: Pyramid H1 at the archaeological site of Caral (Ruta Caral, ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, ). Photo taken on , during a visit to the site.

A few millennia later, Teotihuacan in Mesoamerica flourished, with a population of approximately 100,000, making it the sixth-largest city in the world at its peak (INAH, ).

Figure 2: Overview of Teotihuacan. Photo taken on , during a visit to the site.

Another issue regarding Indigenous history is the oversimplification of historical periods based solely on the Bronze and Iron Ages. Metallurgical evidence shows that Indigenous peoples in America (Abya Yala), practiced metalworking with copper (Cu), silver (Ag), and gold (Au) for over three millennia in the southern regions (Guédron, S., et al., ). Furthermore, maritime trade likely facilitated the spread of these technologies throughout the continent (Hosler, D., ).

Challenges of historical periodization

The periodization of history in the Americas (Abya Ayala) presents unique challenges when compared to Europe. Can the same periods used to define European history be applied to the Americas (Abya Yala)? Before answering this, it is essential to better understand the concept of periodization.

Mathematics in History

Mathematical limits (Natural limits) play a crucial role in defining archaeological periods. Typically, the classification of a period is based on the emergence of specific tools or innovations, such as the use of metal.

When a new tool or innovation is identified, it marks the beginning of a period (the minimum value), often characterized by simpler forms. As time progresses, these tools evolve, reaching their maximum development.

In the Americas (Abya Ayala), however, tools and technologies followed a different evolutionary path compared to Europe. This led to the development of distinct archaeological periods. Furthermore, regions like Mesoamerica and the Andes had their own particularities, which influenced regional timelines significantly (Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México; National Museum of the American Indian). For deeper insight, we recommend consulting the works of John Howland Rowe (Rowe, J. H., , pp. 265 - 266 ; Rowe, J. H., ).

### Periods of Africa

When we speak of humanity in Africa, limiting ourselves only to the last few millennia, when writing emerged, can lead readers to erroneous conclusions. Among the innumerable qualities existing on this continent is the possibility of using, in depth, interdisciplinarity to understand the origin of our species.

The Natural History Museum has a chart demonstrating the evolution of hominins until reaching our species (<htcite0>). On this page, we reproduce part of the chart, associating it with what we will study.
Chart 1: Simplified cladogram of our species.

Next, we present a table related to the periods of the African continent. As content from other nations is introduced to History Tracers, it will continue to be updated. Furthermore, we will also place side by side the period used by European scholars (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>) to simplify comparisons.

text.text:
Reflection 1: We are all...

Have you ever stopped to think that we are all African?

Archaeological Periods in the Americas (Abya Yala)

While it is generally accepted that human presence on the American continent dates back approximately 13,500 years, recent studies suggest the possibility of an earlier arrival, around 30,000 years ago (Roca-Rada, Xavier, et al., , pp. 2 ; Becerra-Valdivia, L., Higham, T., ; Pirula, ). These discrepancies highlight the evolving nature of knowledge (Ferro Virginia, Maria. Virgina ), facilitated by the scientific method (History Tracers, , Scientific Method).

For clarity, we will use the most widely recognized timeframes found in various scholarly sources:

text.text: In different regions, similar names may refer to distinct historical periods. To avoid confusion, it is advisable to always pair period names with their respective region.

### Conclusion The classification of historical periods is inherently tied to the unique development of specific regions. Applying European periodization to other parts of the world, such as the Americas (Abya Yala), can lead to inaccuracies and misunderstandings of local histories. Additionally, these period definitions are subject to change as new discoveries and research continue to reshape our understanding.
